userreviews.userReview: Posted at HeradasThese stories and photos are powerful. They are a more accurate representation of American greatness than any idealized non-existent past that some are eager to return to. America is already great, and these people prove it.The first half of the book contains pre-election writing, and I can’t help but feel a sense of dread and impotent omniscience reading this along with the knowledge of what ended up happening on election day, and the continual trainwreck that has followed since then. The stories are hopeful and heartbreaking. It’s wonderful to see so many different kinds of people coming together in an attempt to stop a disaster. Up until about 8pm that night, it seemed to be a sure thing that Clinton would be the next President of the United States, and against all odds (and the majority of Americans’ votes) Donald Trump won.The day after the election was terrible. I live in a small university town that is generally a pocket of reason in an otherwise notoriously under-informed backwater state. Close to my work there’s a small coffee shop that I walk to when I need to stretch my legs a bit. I usually get coffee and a bagel a couple times a week, and it’s always a bustling, vibrant place. Cheery faces with kind, hopeful demeanors. Youthful, artistic energy. That early November morning everyone was still in a state of shock, thousand yard stares on their faces, envisioning what kind of future we might have now that the worst possible candidate that has ever existed, was elected to the office of President of the United States by a minority of the voting public. There was a sense of hopelessness in everyone I saw. I think we all felt like we were just going through the motions of our lives, unsure what we were doing. No one thought he could win, the whole thing was an absurd joke, until it wasn't. Now, everyone was on edge, and in the midst of an existential crisis.The second half of the book is post election, and these events are still very fresh in my mind. It’s comprised of reactions to the news that our votes didn’t matter this year, and yes, Americans really are misinformed enough that almost 46% of them thought a reality television character was the best option for Commander in Chief. And for some reason that was enough to elect him to office. This is where the stories became the most emotionally powerful for me. People pull together, we regroup, we redouble, we protest in large and small ways, and we keep working toward the type of future that we want. It’s good stuff, and highly motivating.As I’m writing this, Robert Mueller and his team are investigating  the Russian interference in our 2016 election, and it’s starting to look like Donald Trump’s presidency might be one of the shortest in the history of the United States. I am very eager to see this monomaniacal bond villain caricature’s tenure come to a quick and decisive end. Although, his line of succession is equally terrifying. Hopefully they’re all tied tightly into his many crimes, and will go down together, RICO style. It’s a beautiful dream, but I realize it’s most likely just a dream. In reality, powerful people often get away with it.This is a difficult book for me to review because it keeps forcing me to imagine how things could’ve been different in the 2016 election. As they say, Hindsight is 20/20, and looking back with some perspective, I don’t think Clinton was the right candidate to defeat a monster like Trump. I’m a humanist, feminist, atheist and generally liberal leaning dude, but I pay enough attention to history to never call myself a Democrat or a Republican. I know how quickly these divisions can mutate into something they were never meant to be. Just look at the neo-conservative, alt-right takeover of the Republican party in the last ten years. I feel terrible for legitimate conservatives who have no representation in our government anymore. The GOP has completely lost its mind, and I fear that the DNC may be in the midst of a similar problem.Personally, I’ve never been an avid fan of Hillary Clinton. I think her statements against the LGBTQ+ community in the past have been appalling (something she’s very recently started to change, thankfully). But she was undeniably the much, much better candidate of the two options that were presented to us last year, and I voted for her wholeheartedly.I’m still very disturbed by both the DNC and the GOP’s behavior in the primary elections. The best candidates from each camp did not make it to the general election; the most incendiary ones did. The ones that banks and plutocrats knew they could leverage for their own benefit. I understand how necessary representation is, and I genuinely hope our next President is a woman. Girls and women everywhere seeing themselves reflected in such a powerful position, would carry an unknowable importance and a far reaching, generational effect. If Clinton had won, I would’ve been extremely pleased, but there would always be a sliver of disappointment that it wasn’t someone even better. I can only hope that the DNC stops playing the games they’ve been playing and realizes the only way forward is to let the people be heard with a candidate that is genuinely incorruptible and won’t cower to money, or dogma's influence. That is, if such a candidate is allowed to exist within the realm of the established party in 2020.Whoever that ends up being, whatever their gender, sexuality, race, religion, I do not care. I’ll support THAT candidate wholeheartedly. And in the meantime? Midterm elections are the most important thing we can put our energy into right now. We need better congressional and senatorial representation. I want a president who represents the people of this country, and I can't accept that Donald Trump is an accurate representation of us.

I wanted to read this book, even though before I started I figured I had probably already read most of it via the Facebook group posts, and even though I (correctly) predicted that I wouldn’t enjoy reading the book as much as I did finding one timely post after another in the group. There are still new posts being frequently posted.It turned out that I had missed reading or don’t remember reading a fair number of posts chosen for inclusion in the book. I’d joined the group before the election and the mood there was excited and lighthearted. Since Election Day it’s been more of a support group, but the posts continue to be heartwarming, inspirational, and worth reading, though I miss reading most of what’s posted. There is just too much to take the time to read. The group is more fun and enjoyable than the book partly because I get more from them when I read the posts one by one, even if I sometimes read a bunch in a row. I enjoy the stories & photos and I’m grateful that the group exists. For those who are members of Facebook I recommend following some of the group posts.For those who are not Facebook members and cannot access the group’s posts, read the book. People’s stories & photos are worth reading/viewing. It’s uplifting to read about others’ struggles, triumphs, and their resistance. I love the inclusiveness and collective (short story) storytelling and wonderful photos. I like that so many members of marginalized groups, often scorned by the current administration, are speaking up and telling their stories and the stories of family members. The participants are a true melting pot of people of various genders, relationships, religions, races, and ages, abilities/disabilities, individuals, couples, families, friends, simply telling their truths. I also realize that one reason the group’s posts resonate with me more than those in the book is because one of the great things about the group is how each post gets different types of “likes” and many comments, and often those add immeasurably to the original posts. I love seeing the support the posters get and love giving it too. I’ve never posted in the group and have rarely commented, but I do enjoy liking, loving, sad facing, angry facing, etc. people I want to support. When I joined the group I think there were maybe 100,000 people in it. (I don’t remember the exact number; I wish that I did.) Now there are nearly 4 million people in it. I’m so glad that it continued on past election day!: https://www.facebook.com/groups/pants...

This book is equal parts moving and inspiring. The stories are so authentic and come from such a real place that they really moved me. And I feel inspired because there is so much hope and love in these pages in a time when there is so little of that going around. Loved it.

5.0 Stars (man it's been a while since I gave a legitimate 5 star rating to a book: it feels good.)This book is a powerful collection of voices from all walks of life sharing in their experiences on the 2016 election and empowering people to have courage and speak up. It is a fairly political book, so those that are strong Trump supporters would not like this, though I believe everyone should read this for the feel-good courage it injects into the reader. This book will give you a fresh perspective on your neighbors from every background imaginable. Almost like Humans of New York but focusing on the 2016 election.

This book brings us America. We are introduced to a variety of people we might not otherwise encounter, and witness as they open their hearts and speak their experiences. We are presented with a more comprehensive picture of those who love and live and build this country. Not the hate, nor the short dramatic blurbs of the evening news. Ordinary and extraordinary people. Fears and dreams, triumphs and goals. The pictures are captivating, and the words will stay with you long after you've closed the back cover.

I laughed, I cried - for me this book recreated the emotional experience of the end of the 2016 presidential election through the Women's March in January of 2017. By weaving together authentic voices from all over America and images from all over the world, Chamberlain created a portrait of America not often represented by the media or by politics. In short, Pantsuit Nation gave me hope.
This book represents the America I know -- it is hopeful and beautiful and curious and kind and inclusive. It feels pain. It resists. It persists. It is us.
This book is beautiful and painful and hopeful and tangible. It is a wonderful way to share the contributors' experiences and connect.

Though I am biased, due to my work in Pantsuit Nation, the Facebook group, this is an honest and unsolicited review. The book is set up chronologically, starting just before the election, with hope and love. The transition through the book, from hope to fear to hope again, is moving and strong. There are parts that made me laugh, and parts that made me cry. It's emotionally evocative and very real. It ends on a note of hope- looking to the future, and knowing that we're part of making it what we need. I also felt very represented in its pages- as a mother, as a woman, as an adoptive mother, as a mother of a special needs child. This is a very special book, and I am so glad it exists in the world.

Should be required reading for anyone seeking elected office at any level. Filled with stories that explain in clear and concise ways why the personal is political, with a through line that highlights why different layers of activism intersect with each other.This book provides a valuable look at the zeitgeist of late October 2016 through the Woman's March. Sociologists, therapists, political scientists and anyone who believes in the art of storytelling to raise awareness and impact change will especially enjoy this. Have a box of tissue handy. Some of these stories will make you cry.

I didn't know about this (and I believe myself to be well-informed) until I saw this at my library while browsing. Pantsuit Nation, a group on Facebook, started last year to safely talk and support those that supported Hillary Clinton. I loved the format- individuals that posted to the group had their stories told in this book. Some are a picture, others a sentence, and others a few pages. I also liked the timeline- the beginning is before November 8th 2016 and ending on Jan 21st 2017. It helps to know you are not alone. Recommended!See also: http://www.pantsuitnation.org/

Read it. Read it again. I got this book for my birthday from my friends, they had no idea that I was part of Pantsuit Nation or what it was but picked it for me because of the inspiring photos on the cover. However this book (and Facebook posts) have taught me, welcomed me, and prepared me for the fight against Trump. These stories have provided me with smiles, tears, and laughs. Please read this collection of stories to broaden your horizon and learn about the amazing people that surround our country!

So, I'm completely biased about this book, but I LOVE IT SO MUCH. This utilizes the power of storytelling to spread compassion and understanding, which is everything I love. It made me cry and gave me hope.

Sitting and reading this book this morning made me cry. It is a lovely book - and reminds me how far we have to go and how many people are with us. Pantsuit Nation started as a Facebook page where people would share their support for Hillary Clinton in the 2016 election and share their stories. Some of the stories are moving and full of love and others are heartbreaking stories of sexual abuse and discrimination. But all of the stories, all of the post are full of HOPE. The stories are of women and men full of love and acceptance and strength. Immediately after the election I couldn't read the stories, it was all so devastating. Now, a few months in, I can go back and feel empowered and strong. We have so much work to do. But I believe there are more of us who believe LOVE IS LOVE and equality for all and kindness is key. Thank you for this wonderful message!
This book is so AMAZING!
Like Humans of New York but Hillary campaign and post-election instead.

“Stories Spark Change.”This was an amazing set of stories and posts from men and women around the world sharing with STRANGERS on a Facebook page, their expiriences throughout this past election, they shared their fears after the election and what they are going to do now. Thank you Pantsuit Nation. You’ve inspired me and I am so proud to be apart of this amazing movement. Share your stories, they are important in learning and growing and moving forward. Let’s empower each other and inspire each other. Also, thank you Hillary Clinton for inspiring this group. #NastyWomen #PantsuitNation #HRC #EmmaShawReads2018

I find books derived from internet things pretty hit or miss, but surprisingly Pantsuit Nation works well. I remember being highly skeptical when I saw Libby's initial post about how stories were going to be published (is she getting permission? Who profits? etc.) but with a platform, you can do good, and I'm glad to see the secret Facebook event has grown into a blend of online engagement via storytelling and activism. The book itself is laid out chronologically, and vignettes & photos are formatted beautifully- amazing what happens when content is pulled out of the FB format. From the note at the end, it sounds like users submitted their own posts for physical publication, and people are credited appropriately as they wish (some people with just a name & a state, others with their full name, etc.) What's missing is the engagement derived from being posts in the group- it's hard to have subthreads and dialogues in an organized way in vignettes, I suppose. Great snapshots for people who are FB averse, though.

I'm glad I picked up this book last week. While I don't believe in facebook and have serious problems with its privacy and trademark policies, I was aware of Pantsuit Nation during the 2016 Presidential Campaign, and as a woman who worked for nearly a decade in an environment extremely unfriendly to her liberal, LGBTQIA+, feminist, environmentalist, equality-minded self, I was grateful that someone, in this case LIbby Chamberlain, had created an online space for people like me to come together and share their stories. I would argue that this book, and this group, is now more important than ever; it certainly made me feel more connected this week as I tried to distract myself from the path of absolute destruction the current administration seems set on continuing.Thank you to all the contributors, and to the folks who made its creation possible. Let's keep sharing. Let's keep supporting one another. It's the only way we're gonna make it through.

I enjoyed this book as I was a follower of Pantsuit Nation when Hillary Clinton was running for President and still read posts now and then. The photos and stories are a kaleidoscope of humanity expressing all that we are and all that we feel. The positive emotions felt going into that election, watching the results in horror, and then the sadness & depression following the election are all captured. The most important message this book conveys is hope and inspiration because I know there are millions of people that share the same dreams for each other and our country as I do. And we will make it there!

I believe a book should touch your emotions and Pantsuit Nation certainly accomplished that! From the far edges of anger and despair to the lightness and fulfillment of love and understanding. The images are outstanding with some I just couldn't stop staring at (see page 28!!)I felt so AT HOME in this book, and so at home with the writers. I wanted to hug some of them to assure them they aren't alone. That is what Pantsuit Nation is about.Read your copy and pass it on - it's what I'm going to do!

Pantsuit Nation is a life-affirming look at today's Americans who have made it their mission to listen, encourage, speak up, and feel empowered to share their stories in uncertain political times. The stories in this book are as diverse as the people who tell them, but what unifies them is a shared belief that differences are what makes America strong. The book was born on Facebook, but the physical book that it has become is tremendously effective, with modern, crisp design, large photos, and pull quotes with larger fonts. I felt uplifted, inspired, and empowered when I finished it.

Equally dismaying and uplifting, this book transported me back to the months surrounding the 2016 election. I'm glad I waited this long before reading, as it would have been too fresh earlier. Man, that was an emotional roller coaster of a time. However, this book finishes with references to the Women's March, one of the most inspirational movements I've ever seen and that is the key take away. We are not alone, empathy fuels progess and love trumps hate; even if the current systems are working against us.

A stunning collection of inspiring stories and photographs, Pantsuit Nation is a beautifully rendered book. Beginning as a small Facebook group in November 2016, Pantsuit Nation quickly grew with an organic gusto. Chamberlain has done a fabulous job curating stories from that group, for this book. Truly inspiring!

This book is a beautiful assemblage of photos and personal stories representing the diversity of hope in the USA. It's a celebration of the passion for justice that connects the people whose stories and faces are portrayed -- it's not really about the campaign or the candidate they were campaigning for -- and I enjoyed getting to know each of these people a little bit.

If you want a reminder of the diversity, love and need for love in our country, read this book. It's a collection of people's stories, just tiny little tidbits but the depth of heart contained in these pages is staggering.

This book is the 21st century equivalent of 1970s consciousness raising. The power of these stories connects deeply with my own story of last year's election and all the other campaigns I've supported over the decades The personal is political. Again and anew.
So many amazing stories! This collection shows the power of storytelling on a national/global scale and I am here for it.
Inspiring. Beautiful photography. Well done.
Wonderful pictures. Wonderful stories. Wonderful movement.

description: An inspiring collection of stories and photographs that captures what it means to live, work, love, and resist in America, from the Facebook group with millions of engaged and impassioned members. In October 2016, Maine resident Libby Chamberlain created a secret Facebook group encouraging a handful of friends to wear pantsuits to the polls. Overnight, the group of thirty exploded to 24,000 members. By November 8th, the group was three-million strong. Since Pantsuit Nation's inception, its members have shared personal stories that illustrate the complexities of living in a vibrant, oftentimes contentious democracy. Members turn to Pantsuit Nation as a place of refuge and inspiration, where marginalized voices are amplified, faces are put to political decisions, resources are shared, and activism is ignited. It is a dynamic, diverse community united by an unwavering commitment to building a more just, inclusive world.Now, hundreds of Pantsuit Nation members have contributed their stories and photographs to form this extraordinary book. An indelible testament to the idea that change comes first from the heart, and that the surest way to move a heart is to tell a story, Pantsuit Nation is a portrait of a moment in history and a rallying cry for our time.
title: Pantsuit Nation
